Perhaps I wasn't clear.  There may be a large
number of messages and, ideally, I only want the
client to retrieve new messages.

Again, my initial instinct here was that I could
use range-headers (because the mailbox only
grows), but, even if I just return metadata, I
want to give the server the option of moving the
actual messages to different URLs.

Unfortunately, there is no guarantee that the new
URL will have the same length as the old.  So
changing all the URLs in the folder could
radically change its length, thereby precluding
use of range headers to get new messages.

Does this make sense now?

-Alex-

PS I really want the server to be able to choose
on a per-message basis whether to return the
whole message or simply a URL but URL changes
illustrate my pount sufficiently well.

On Sun, 5 Jan 2003, S. Mike Dierken wrote:

>
> ----- Original Message -----
> From: "S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
>
> > I am trying to figure out how to create a ReST
> > interface to a mailfolder.
> >
> > Initially, I figured I could simply POST messages
> > and have them appended to the mailfolder and then
> > GET with range-headers to see if anyone has added
> > anything new since the last time I checked the
> > folder.
> When you GET, is the response a list of current messages or the actual
> content of the messages?
> I'd go with a list of messages & use last-modified/if-modified-since, etc.
> to check for new messages.
>
>
> > Any thoughts on how to solve this without forcing
> > the client to GET the entire folder each time?
> Get a collection of references to messages, each with a little metadata.
> Retrieve content with later requests.
>
>
> -- ask for snapshot of inbox, providing username/password --
> GET /pop/user-99/inbox/ HTTP/1.1
> Authentication: Basic WZYSHS=
>
> -- snapshot of inbox --
> Content-Type: text/xml
>
> <folder>
>  <item href='/pop/user-99/msgs/msg1024' from='joe@...' />
> </folder>
>
>
>
>
